messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Paulownia ?????
messages.msgSnippet:
Aoi heartvine motif seems to be similar if not identical to the vine
arabesque detail also noted on some museum preserved aoi-crested Palanquin -
norimono,
messages.messageBody:
Aoi "heartvine" motif seems to be similar if not identical to the vine
arabesque detail also noted on some museum preserved aoi-crested Palanquin -
norimono,
Initially thought that it was a honeysuckel Nindou "tsuruha" flower or
half flower.

U may want to also reference the "JAANUS" home page & search engine -
Japanese Architecture & Art Net User System ,Page for additional info on
various Japanese - other mons / arabesque / karakusa designs.

Rick

karakusa.

milt

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Paulownia ?????
messages.msgSnippet: Plants are definitely not my strong suit. I stoop to the plant people. Gordon ... From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@EARTHLINK.NET] Sent: Saturday, January
messages.messageBody:
Plants are definitely not my strong suit. I stoop to the plant people.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Saturday, January 08, 2005 9:15 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Paulownia ?????



Gordon,
My Japanese plant books show tachi-aoi as a species of trillium. The leaves
are quite different from ones in an aoi mon and again the flowers don't
match the ones on the bowl.

The plant in the aoi mon is often called hollyhock in English, but that's
yet another very different group of plants. Working with the common names
of plants is confusing enough without dealing with approximate translations,
too. Agreed that the vines don't belong to the leaves/mon.

Jim



Sorry, I just read Jim's discussion, but I think the plant used for the
Tokugawa mon and that on this bowl is the tachi-aoe or hollyhock. Also,
the
vines and what not, are not tachi-aoe elements, but closer to karakusa or
arabesques/foliage and are often found in lacquered pieces. I have a
naginata pole with the same arabesques and mon (different mon).



Gordon

Sent: Saturday, January 08, 2005 8:28 AM

Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Paulownia ?????



This entire motif is Aoe either as a mon or as a plant.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: RCorbin [mailto:nihonto@...]
Sent: Friday, January 07, 2005 10:30 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Paulownia ?????



It may also be part of the Aoi plant (futuba-aoi), mallow or birthwort
family (uma no suzukusa) or "Wild Ginger". Presented on the lacquer ware in
arabesque pattern/motif.

Rick

all, is the smaller of the flower/leaves ( on the vine ) on this design

is the smaller ones I am trying to place.

Cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Paulownia ?????
messages.msgSnippet: Rick, The flower stalk at the left is pretty clearly drawn as coming from the same stem as the two aoi leaves (that are not part of a mon).  My first thought
messages.messageBody:
Rick,
The flower stalk at the left is pretty clearly drawn as coming from the same stem as the two aoi leaves (that are not part of a mon). My first thought was the same as yours, but as far as I've been able to find, the aoi that is depicted in the famous mon is Asarum caulescens, which is as you say a wild ginger and pretty similar to the European and North American varieties. None of them have flowers like that, let alone the vine-like habit suggested by the arabesques. Looking into the popular names for these plants is confusing -- I may be missing something essential, but I suspect that the lacquer artist was working backward from the mon and just mixed in parts from other plants to go with the aoi leaves.

Jim

It may also be part of the Aoi plant (futuba-aoi), mallow or birthwort
family (uma no suzukusa) or "Wild Ginger". Presented on the lacquer ware in
arabesque pattern/motif.

Rick


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko Akasaka
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The term Ko-Akasaka is usually applied to the work of the first three generations, who left no known signed tsuba.  (BTW, there are only a few known
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The term Ko-Akasaka is usually applied to the work of the first three generations, who left no known signed tsuba. (BTW, there are only a few known guards signed by Tadamune by the 4th gen.)

The shodai seems to show more Owari influence than Kyo, but that is open to argument and I think that both influences are present.

The tsuba in the photo looks later than the nidai to me, but the design has some early elements.
Jim

p.s.
Sometimes I hear Ko-Akasaka used to describe tsuba with Akasaka-style motifs that otherwise appear to predate the Edo period, i.e. "proto-Akasaka." I don't think I've seen this usage in any Japanese sources though.



All, am I right in thinking that Ko Akasaka is referring to old Akasaka
as in, the Shodai, Nidai and maybe, though I am not convinced, the
Sandai. But the first of the Akasaka smiths ( the oldest ) that had
heavy influence from Kyo sukashi and Owari works. Am I right in this
thinking ?.

and while were at it, this looks like the work of the Nidai Tadamasa or
a student there off, any comment's
http://www.image-hosting.net/images/messageboard/retalt/akasaka.jpg

Cheers and happy new year to you all.

Rich Turner



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
